reviewText: Though I prefer the original Swedish versions of The Pippi Longstocking movies based on the Pippi books by Swedish kids author Astrid Lindgren I thought this remake was cute though having it set in in Florida, U.S.A. was a bit odd. Though not quite as good a Pippi as Inger Nilsson I think Tami Erin did a fine job and had just the right amount of spunk to make her performance seem believable and I think the movie is worth watching at least once but it's not something I would keep but more like a rental or something I might watch on TV if it was on and I had nothing else to do.
summary: Not great but not horrible either!
Title: N/A

reviewText: I enjoyed watching this as a kid, and still maintain that it's a fun movie.  Pippi is allowed to do all the things that kids would love to be able to do -- make a big mess, flip pancakes up in the air and not worry where they land, scoff authority, etc.  However in watching it again I also realized that my kids are too young for this.  There are no consequences for Miss Longstocking, so though the kids liked watching it, it's not really appropriate for young children that think of all older kids as role models.
summary: Fun kids movie, not a role model movie

reviewText: This is a rather weird production:* casting an uncomfortably nubile 14-yo for the title role;* bizarre gymnastic stunts with tinkling fairy-dust sound effects (just in case you missed the "Magic";* funky-pop musical numbers that are as annoyingly catchy as they are awful;* cardboard characterization, choppy editing, hammy acting;* Scooby doo-like voice-unders for the horse and the monkey;* added uncharacteristic weakness and insecurity, detracting from Lindgren's strong, supremely self-confident Pippi.That said, it's pretty okay for the 6-10 yo girl set. I vet all movies before presenting to my 7 yo, and though this one has its good and bad points, it's mostly harmless. Recommended.Actually the best acting is by the girl who plays Annika (Cory Crow), who is sincere, refreshingly unforced, and seems to have had a good time in the production. Whatever happened to HER?

reviewText: For children who grew up in the 1980s, THE NEW ADVENTURES OF PIPPI LONGSTOCKING has always been a cherished title.  Based on the series of books by Astrid Lindgren, it features a vivacious Tami Erin as the title character and a well-cast ensemble.Pippilotta Delicatessa Windowshade Longstocking--Pippi for short--lives with her sea-captain father and enjoys a colourful life, until an horrific storm separates the pair.  Pippi makes her way ashore and sets up housekeeping in a rambling old house called Villa Villekula; and later makes two new friends, Tommy and Annika Settigren (David Seaman and Cory Crow).  But Pippi also faces a tough enemy in the stern orphanage owner Miss Bannister (Eileen Brennan), and the rest of the town authorities.THE NEW ADVENTURES OF PIPPI LONGSTOCKING was the long-awaited followup to the fondly remembered 1969-1970 Swedish film franchise (starring Inger Nilsson in the title role).  Fans of the original movies have always treated it with contempt, and while it does create some slight liberties with the original material, it does stay true to the whimsical and carefree themes which were hallmarks of the books.Tami Erin, if slightly too old for the role, gives a solid and heartfelt performance as Pippi.  David Seaman and Cory Crow are a bit too goody-goody, but that contrasts perfectly with Pippi's irreverent nature.  The always amazing Eileen Brennan steals many a scene with her hilarious role of the mean orphanage mistress.  Dennis Dugan and Dianne Hull play the Settigren parents, with Conrad John Schuck as Pippi's father.The theme song is very catchy.  You'll find yourself humming it for weeks--though I'm not sure whether that's a good or bad thing!  I remember growing up with this movie, and it has been really fun to see it again on DVD.

reviewerName: Chaiam Yankel's bubbie "Bubbie near and far"
reviewText: The Pippi Longstocking books are weird, but this movie is just clunky and limps along, trying to breathe some life into a sanitized version of a weird story. The whole thing is pretty wooden; it lacks real spark. On the other hand, my 5 year old and 3 year old grandsons watched the whole thing with me, so it kept their attention without any whiz-bang noise they're used to in Cars or Airplanes or Despicable Me. So:  three stars, but barely.

reviewText: I'll address the one person (I'm sure that'll change) that gave this movie one star. Yes, it is true that this movie does not follow the books. In fact, they're taking artistic license all over the place, but that doesn't detract from the experience. The reason I read the books in the first place was because of this movie. Anyway, on to the real review. It's very light fare. A children's film. I have memories of watching it when I was younger and I enjoyed it. I still do. So, if you're looking for something you can watch with the kids, of if you're a big kid (like me), get this film. And unlike most "kids" movies you see today there is no bathroom humor. Highly recommended.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Arrogant is a good one.  Another is rascal.  Other ones that fit rather well are show-stopper, shameless, unrepentent, metahuman, Goddess, and powerful almost to the point of being menacing but not quite.  You need only fear her if your life depends on NOT having fun.Oh, yeah.  And she's probably older and smarter than she pretends to be, and she's definitely MUCH wiser.All these things have made her one of my favorite fictional characters ever.So why is it that in this movie, she is none of those amazing things?As a child, I was a fairly poor individual, not at all like Pippi, but I did have a library card, and so I spent much time reading.  Naturally, when this movie came out, I couldn't go to see it, however, I did read the book, and I was immediately swept up into a childhood crush on its main character that lasted for years and years.At the age of 18 or so, I finally got the chance to see this movie, and I was apalled!  This film makes a mockery of everything Pippi is.For about 70% of the film, Pippi behaves completely out-of-character, and much of the rest of it is consumed by lousy characters who have no substance.  Pippi does get to rough up a few people, but unlike in the books, she only does it to three bad guys that act like the Curly, Larry and Moe.Additionally, this movie is plagued by the curse of having way too many unnecesary songs.  It could have been so much better.If you want to speak kindly of this movie, however, you won't be entirely without ammunition.  It does contain a few scenes of pleasing metahuman powers, and several of Pippi being a brat which ALMOST threaten to drag the movie out of the gutter it made for itself.If you still don't understand what I'm griping about, read all three Pippi books, then carefully review the scenes in the children's home.  You should be able to tell quite easily that none of them should have happened, especially the one where Pippi flinches at the striking of a ruler, as opposed to her book incarnation, whose skin was about the consistency of a brick wall.Long and short, as a movie, it's only marginally bad, but you definitely don't want to watch it because frankly, you're better off reading the books by about a billion times.
summary: What words can describe Pippi Longstocking?

reviewerName: Lilli Winston "Childhood is short. Toys are fun."
reviewText: I grew up watching Pippi and wanted to introduce her to my kids. What is better place to start thenreading reviews of all the available versions of the DVDsMy original instinct was to go with what I used to watch as  a kid. I almost bought the old original versionbut then I decided to see the youtube trailers of old original movies and new adventures movie.I was shocked to find out that I completely outgrew the slow pace and frankly rather boaringand hardly keeping me from yawning old version and when I clicked the new adventures trailerthat felt more like home.It is possible that throught the year something happened.. either my attention span changedor maybe the movies in the old days were just so slow paced that it did not bothered mebut today I think that it is really hard to watch old versions.The voice over did not bothered me at all as I am sued to watching foreign moviesbut the whole slooooooow action is really hard to watch.I would say that for an older viewer who just want to see original that might be an optionbut if you have new generation younger kid who is used to modern movies it mightblow the whole effect and instead of having your kid interested you can get a kiddisinterested completely.I am glad I watched the trailers and compared and made decision based onmy family preferences and my own and my kids abilities to watch certain typeof cinematography.I am not saying this movie is for everyone as I red some complaining on moderndisney'esk flavor of it, I like it and it is well made and of course you can't have both.you either have this one or the other.. unless you can have both?My recommendation though is if you get old and this versions -do watch the old first as afer watching new adventures it is really pain toslow down with perception to watch the old version.

reviewerName: Lonnie E. Holder "The Review's the Thing"
reviewText: Pippi is a magical girl that seems simultaneously wise and nave.  When you begin to watch this film you wonder whether Pippi makes up all the things she talks about, or whether she can actually do them.  When Pippi flies, you know there is something about her that is magical.Pippi is an outcast because she behaves strangely, and yet everyone quickly accepts her because she is so self-assured and has wonderful faith.  Pippi is simply unafraid to try.  While some of the things she does are socially bizarre, she also makes a role model for young girls and boys.  How often do we tell our children that they should not be afraid to try something new?  Pippi's life is has one constant, and that is always trying something new.Besides being willing to try something new, Pippi revels in being a child.  She enjoys food fights and walking up and down walls.  Her tales of pirates and cannibals lend a tinge of Peter Pan to the proceedings.  Eventually you want to believe everything she says is real and has happened to her.  It is impossible to prove they have not happened to her.My children loved this movie, and watched it several times.  I suspect that Pippi was able to break rules that my children could not, and Pippi's unwillingness to accept convention fascinated them.  Whatever the reason children love this movie, it is good harmless fun.Enjoy!

reviewText: I have to admit, this movie is creative with its portrayal of the characters. However, I get the feeling that the film is painfully low-budget. While the main trio of kids capture their characters, the writing makes them very bland, uninteresting characters. Pippi still has the carefree attitude and friendliness that Lindgren's writing conveyed, but Tommy and Annika both seem to have lost any personality they had originally, and they originally only really existed to be shown as ordinary middle-class children. The storyline is very good, and the movie is appealing to younger viewers. However, the sub-plot of the men hoping to tear down Villa Villikulla feels like they're trying to pad the film out, and it would have been better to leave that out.Overall, the movie is worth a watch once, but you'd be better off reading the books about Pippi.

reviewText: This film is one of those rare "extreme" triple-threats:  extreme bad acting; extreme bad script; extreme bad directing/editing!  All of these combined to make for a dual rating from myself:  1 star for being one of the worst movies ever made, and yet 5 stars for being one of the worst movies ever made, but SO much fun to watch and make fun of.  Not being familiar with the original story or the characters involved, I come from just a film buff stand point and I have to say that this ranks #2 on my list of all time favorite worst movies. The lead actress in the role of Pippi comes off as a mental patient in a red wig set loose upon an unsuspecting town.  Her "medicated" style of acting is humorously manic in a cold-reading sort of way. Out of 8,000 hopefuls who auditioned for this role, this was the best they found? Yikes! However, when it comes down to brass tacks, this film always succeeds in making me laugh; something most bad films would love to settle for.
